doc.field: Drop in Cebit Home attendance figures

Significantly fewer people have visited the second Cebit Home trade fair in Hannover. Around 180 000 people attended in the last five days, whereas 215 000 attended the fair two years ago. However, most of the exhibitors were still either satisfied or very satisfied with the numbers. In particular, computer and video game exhibitors had very positive reactions from the public.

Many tenants will be faced with rent increases in the next few weeks. The reason for this is the so-called cut-off rate for dwellings built before 1980 costing over DM 8 per square meter, excluding overheads, no longer applies as from September 1st. Rents can now be increased by 30% per annum instead of only 20% for all buildings concerned.

Three teenagers robbed two gas stations in Munich on Saturday night. A masked 16-year-old looted DM 900 at a gas station in the Bodenseestrasse, although he was caught and arrested at the Pasing S-Bahn station a while later. Two masked teenage girls also tried to rob a gas station in the Ingolstadter Strasse at around two in the morning. The garage attendant did not let himself be intimidated by them and the two girls, aged thirteen and fifteen, had to flee without loot. They were also arrested within a short time.
Merkel demands guarantees regarding millennium changeover

Angela Merkel, Federal Minister of the Environment, has demanded that nuclear power stations provide proof that their computers are equipped to deal with the changeover into the year 2000 without problem. A spokesman for the ministry in Bonn confirmed a newspaper report in this regard. The international nuclear energy authorities are also investigating the reliability of computers in nuclear power stations worldwide.

Berlin's senator for internal affairs, Joerg Schoenbom, has announced further deportations of Bosnian refugees. The CDU politician said to the "Berliner Zeitung" newspaper that the time for hospitality has now come to an end. Mr. Schoenbom assumes that the number of Bosnian refugees in Berlin will be reduced by around four to five thousand by the end of December. He predicted that around 15 000 to 16 000 Bosnian refugees will still be living in Berlin at the end of the year.
